figures.description: Total‑utility curve for Question 7. Horizontal axis: Quantity; vertical axis: Total Utility. The curve rises, reaches a maximum at point M and then bends downwards. Marginal utility at any quantity is the slope of the TU curve; at point M the slope is zero.

Demand and supply table for eggs in Question 24. Columns: price per dozen (₦), quantity demanded (dozens) and quantity supplied (dozens). Data: ₦100 → Qd 410, Qs 570; ₦90 → Qd 450, Qs 530; ₦80 → Qd 490, Qs 490; ₦70 → Qd 530, Qs 450; ₦60 → Qd 570, Qs 410. Equilibrium occurs when Qd = Qs at ₦80.

Short‑run cost diagram for Question 20. U‑shaped average variable‑cost (AVC) curve and marginal‑cost (MC) curve; the upper envelope labelled T is the long‑run average‑cost curve. Segment UT of the MC curve above the minimum point of AVC represents the firm’s short‑run supply curve in a perfectly competitive market.

Labour‑market diagram for Question 36. Vertical axis: wage (W); horizontal axis: labour. Upward‑sloping supply curve of labour S_L and downward‑sloping demand curve D_L. Three horizontal wage lines W₁, W₂ and W₃ and a higher line W_F are drawn, showing different wage rates; the lowest one indicates the minimum wage.

instructions.text: In each of questions 1 to 50, choose the option that best answers the question or completes the statement.

questions.question: If the price elasticity of demand for a good is 0.43, an increase in the price of the good will result in
questions.explanation: With \(|E_d| = 0.43 < 1\), demand is inelastic; a price increase raises total revenue and hence profit, giving a **net gain**.

questions.question: In a free‑market economy the price system allocates resources
questions.explanation: The price system directs resources to their **most valued alternative uses**.

questions.question: At consumer equilibrium, the slope of the indifference curve is

options.text: half the slope of the budget‑constraint line
equal to the slope of the budget‑constraint line
greater than the slope of the budget‑constraint line
less than the slope of the budget‑constraint line

questions.explanation: Equilibrium occurs when **MRS = price ratio**, i.e. slope of indifference curve equals slope of budget line.

questions.question: For a supply curve, an increase in the price of a commodity will result in

options.text: a decrease in the quantity supplied
an increase in the quantity supplied

questions.explanation: A movement **upwards along** a given supply curve corresponds to an **increase in quantity supplied**.

questions.question: A normal good with close substitutes is likely to have price elasticity of demand
questions.explanation: Close substitutes make demand **price‑elastic** (\(|E_d| > 1\)).

questions.question: Economics is regarded as a social science because it

options.text: adopts the scientific method in production
applies the scientific method in the study of human behaviour

questions.explanation: Economics is a social science since it **uses scientific methods** to study human economic behaviour.

questions.question: The diagram in figure Econ2001_TU_Curve shows the total‑utility curve. At the point M, marginal utility
questions.explanation: Marginal utility is the **slope of TU**; at the maximum of TU (point M) the slope is zero.

questions.question: A change in supply is best described as a

options.text: shift of the supply curve to the left or to the right
shift of the supply curve to the left
shift of the supply curve to the right

questions.explanation: A **change in supply** (as opposed to quantity supplied) means the whole supply curve shifts.

questions.question: When a generalization is made based on observed facts, it is known as
questions.explanation: **Inductive reasoning** draws general conclusions from specific observations.

questions.question: A major problem facing all economies is how to

options.text: transform from a developing to a developed economy

questions.explanation: The central economic problem is **allocating scarce resources** among competing uses.

questions.question: A vertical supply curve indicates that

options.text: the quantity supplied is responsive to price
the same fixed quantity will be supplied no matter the price
an increase in price will result in an increase in the quantity supplied
there is a fixed price for the commodity below which no supply will be made

questions.explanation: A vertical supply curve is **perfectly inelastic**: quantity is fixed regardless of price.

questions.question: In a demand curve, the relationship between price and quantity is
questions.explanation: Law of demand: price and quantity demanded are **inversely related**.

questions.question: If the arithmetic mean of the numbers \(1, 2, 5, 6, x\) is 8.0, find the value of \(x\).
questions.explanation: The mean is \(\frac{1+2+5+6+x}{5} = 8\Rightarrow 14+x=40\Rightarrow x=26\). None of the visible options matches; the printed data may differ in the original paper.

questions.question: The fixing of the price of an item above or below the equilibrium price is most likely to take place in a
questions.explanation: Price controls (ceilings/floors) are characteristic of a **centrally planned** system.

questions.question: A consumer’s scale of preference is an arrangement of his

options.text: scarce resources in order of importance
sources of income and their importance
requirements and how to satisfy them

questions.explanation: A scale of preference ranks **wants/needs** in order of importance.

questions.question: A firm’s shut‑down point is reached when the average revenue fails to cover the
questions.explanation: Shutdown occurs when **price (AR) < minimum AVC**; the firm cannot cover variable costs.

questions.question: Internal economies of scale are expected to bring about

options.text: an increase in short‑run average cost
an increase in long‑run average cost
a decrease in long‑run average cost
a decrease in short‑run average cost

questions.explanation: Economies of scale reduce **long‑run average cost** as output expands.

questions.question: In the long run, a monopolist maximizes his profit when the marginal cost equals
questions.explanation: Profit maximization condition: **MC = MR**.

questions.question: The long run is a period during which a firm

options.text: sells input to purchase fixed asset
sources all its inputs from within

questions.explanation: In the long run **all factors are variable**.

questions.question: An important feature of perfect competition is that

options.text: the movement of goods and services is restricted
there is adequate knowledge of existing prices
individual economic units can influence prices

questions.explanation: Perfect competition assumes **perfect information** about prices.

questions.question: If government fixes price below the equilibrium price, what effect will it have on demand?

options.text: Quantity demanded and supplied will be equal
Quantity supplied will be greater than quantity demanded

questions.explanation: A price ceiling below equilibrium makes the good cheaper, so **quantity demanded increases** (and excess demand arises).

questions.question: An imperfect market exists where

options.text: there is perfect information among the few buyers and sellers
both buyers and sellers have free entry into and exit from the market
the location of some sellers gives them an advantage over others

questions.explanation: Location advantages and product differentiation create **imperfect competition**.

questions.question: A production function relates
questions.explanation: Production function: \(Q = f(K,L,...)\): relationship between **inputs and output**.

questions.question: Using the demand schedule for eggs (figure Econ2001_DemandSchedule_Eggs), what is the equilibrium price?
questions.explanation: Equilibrium where \(Q_d = Q_s\): at \(P = 80\), \(Q_d = Q_s = 490\).

questions.question: A major advantage of specialization and division of labour is that

options.text: there will be a ready market for labour

questions.explanation: Specialization reduces **time lost in switching tasks**, increasing efficiency.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of a fixed cost?
questions.explanation: Rent on premises does not vary with output in the short run and is a **fixed cost**.

questions.question: In the agricultural sector, improved extension services facilitate
questions.explanation: Extension services help farmers acquire **modern techniques and knowledge**.

questions.question: A disadvantage of concentrating industries in an area is that it could
questions.explanation: Industrial concentration often causes **pollution and congestion**.

questions.question: The losses suffered by a sole proprietor are

options.text: usually equal to the amount invested
usually less than the amount invested
not limited to the amount invested

questions.explanation: A sole proprietor has **unlimited liability**; personal assets may be used to cover business debts.

questions.question: To facilitate the exportation of crude oil from Nigeria, special

options.text: airstrips were constructed for jets to evacuate the oil
roads were built to connect the major oil wells to the ports
pipelines were laid to connect the major oil wells to the ports
railway lines were constructed to connect the major oil wells to the ports

questions.explanation: **Pipelines** are the principal means of moving crude oil from well‑heads to export terminals.

questions.question: An industry is a

options.text: group of firms producing related commodities
group of firms producing distinct commodities

questions.explanation: An industry consists of **all firms producing similar/related products**.

questions.question: The raising of funds by selling stocks to the public is called
questions.explanation: Issuing shares raises **equity capital**.

questions.question: A tax that increases at a higher percentage as income increases is called
questions.explanation: In a **progressive tax**, the average tax rate rises with income.

questions.question: The price paid for labour services is the
questions.explanation: General term for payment to labour is **wage rate**.

questions.question: The capital market is a market for financial assets such as
questions.explanation: Capital markets trade **long‑term securities** (shares, bonds).

questions.question: In national income accounting, NNP is derived by subtracting from the GNP
questions.explanation: Net National Product = **GNP − depreciation**.

questions.question: Economic growth can be accelerated through
questions.explanation: Postponing consumption increases **savings and investment**, speeding growth.

questions.question: An increase in the discount rate is an indication of a Central Bank’s intention to pursue
questions.explanation: Raising the discount (bank) rate discourages borrowing, i.e. **contractionary policy**.

questions.question: The efficiency of labour can be increased by

options.text: retirement of workers on a regular basis

questions.explanation: Training raises workers’ **skills and productivity**.

questions.question: In Nigeria, revenue sharing from the Federation Account is between the

options.text: executive, the judiciary and the legislature
federal and state governments and the parastatals
federal and state governments and the senate

questions.explanation: Federation Account revenues are shared among **federal, state and local governments**.

questions.question: The reduction of high fertility rate is a measure in population control designed to make the

options.text: female population higher than the male
male population higher than the female

questions.explanation: Lower fertility aims at achieving **sustainable population growth**.

questions.question: National debt is an expected outcome of a
questions.explanation: A **budget deficit** must typically be financed by borrowing, adding to national debt.

questions.question: The distribution channel that contributes most to the cost of production is
questions.explanation: The **longest channel** with more middlemen (D) adds the greatest cost margins.

questions.question: Money may not be accepted as a store of value if
questions.explanation: If money’s purchasing power is **unstable**, people will not wish to hold it as a store of value.

questions.question: In order to accelerate economic development a country must

options.text: pursue a high population growth rate

questions.explanation: A **rational population policy** ensures population growth is consistent with resources and development goals.

questions.question: If the labour force in a given community is 2,000,000, the wage‑employed are 200,000 and the unemployed are 80,000, what is the unemployment rate in the community?
questions.explanation: If the labour force is defined as employed plus unemployed (\(200{,}000 + 80{,}000 = 280{,}000\)), then unemployment rate is \(80{,}000/280{,}000 ≈ 28.6\%\), which does not match the visible options. The original data/options may differ; consult the official paper.

questions.question: GNP is not a good measure of social welfare because there are unrecorded
questions.explanation: Many **non‑market social services** and environmental effects are not reflected in GNP.

questions.question: Loans from the World Bank to developing countries are mainly to support
questions.explanation: World Bank lending typically finances **large infrastructure and development projects**.

questions.question: The major reason why nations engage in international trade is that

options.text: it allows free movement of factors of production
it makes possible the use of capital‑intensive methods of production
nations are substantially different in their endowments of economic resources
it affords the trading nations the opportunity to earn high profit

questions.explanation: Countries trade because **resource endowments differ**, giving rise to comparative advantage.

questions.question: A country with an over‑valued currency will most likely

options.text: have increased demand for her exports

questions.explanation: Over‑valuation makes imports cheap and exports dear, causing **BOP deficits** and a fall in foreign‑exchange reserves.
